clinical_study.brief_title: Probiotics Against Pathogenic Bacteria in Connection With Anaesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Probiotics for Reduction of Colonisation With Pathogenic Bacteria in the Oropharynx in Connection With Anaesthesia

brief_summary.textblock:
Longer surgical procedures require intubation and there is a potential risk of contaminating the lower airways with pathogenic bacteria from the mouth and oropharynx.
Healthy people seldom have pathogenic bacteria originating from the gastro-intestinal canal but those do occur among patients, both in those not so sick and patients with more severe problems.
For ICU patients we have seen a reduction of emerging enteric bacteria in patients given oral care with probiotics and this is a pilot study to explore the possibility of the same kind of positive effects in patients due for longer (more than 4 hours of anesthesia) procedures.
Randomisation
- No prophylaxis
- Preparation with a probiotic suspension before intubation.
Cultures
- oropharynx
- before treatment
- after intubation
- before extubation
- day 1 postoperatively
- tracheal secretions
- after intubation
- before extubation

primary_outcome.measure: Differences in pathogenic bacteria in the oropharynx and lower airways
primary_outcome.description: Emerging and resident bacteria will be compared for the cultures taken in the oropharynx and from tracheal secretions in conection with anaestesia and a surgical intervention

secondary_outcome.description: WBC taken pre-op and days 1,2,3 post-op
CRP taken pre-op and days 1,2,3 post-op
X-ray verified infiltrations in combination with expectorates

secondary_outcome.time_frame: time to discharged from hospital or patients death
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of length of stay between the intervention group and the control group

arm_group.description: Patients will gurgle and swallow a mixture of probiotic bacteria
No intervention. What has been the standard procedure so far

intervention.description: Patients will gurgle and swallow a mixture of probiotic bacteria

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients
- Planned interventions
- Anaesthesia > 4 hours and requiring intubation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ulcers in the mouth, oropharynx, oesophagus and stomach
- Current infections in the airways
- Known immuno deficiences
- Emergency cases
